awd_titl_txt: Cybersecurity Advanced Technological Education at a Tribal College
awd_abstract_narration:
Keeping computers and information systems secure is a major challenge. Business, industry, and government need well-prepared technicians who can prevent, detect, and investigate cybersecurity breaches, and the growth of cyber-threats has created a need for many more workers who have the necessary knowledge and skills. To address this nationwide challenge in education and workforce development, this project will establish a cybersecurity program at a tribal college, building a seamless pathway for students to move from high school into an associate degree program in cybersecurity and on to a job or a related bachelor's degree program. The project's overarching goal is to increase the number of students, including Native Americans, veterans, and women, pursuing cybersecurity-focused degrees and technical certifications. The investigators aim to build a replicable model that can be adapted and scaled, especially at other tribal colleges.

This project at Turtle Mountain Community College will build on the college's Computer Support Specialist program, which provides two years of technical computer education leading to an Associate of Applied Science (AAS) degree. Students in the new cybersecurity program will learn skills in computer architecture, operating systems, computer troubleshooting and repair, server administration, network infrastructure design and support, network infrastructure security, and programming. The curriculum will incorporate a hands-on, experiential learning approach. Local employers have committed to provide on-the-job training, job shadowing, and part-time or full-time positions for students. Minot State University's Business Information Technology department will provide professional development for Turtle Mountain Community College faculty, will assist them with developing courses in different formats (on-campus, online, and hybrid), and will support a pathway for students who wish to transfer to the university after completing the two-year degree. The key activities in the project are (1) to develop a new AAS degree in cybersecurity/information assurance that is aligned with the needs of local business and industry; (2) to recruit high school students on or near the Turtle Mountain Indian Reservation into the program through summer camps and other outreach; (3) to encourage students to obtain industry-recognized certifications to validate the skills they learn in the degree program; (4) to utilize connections within the Northern Information Technology Consortium (including Dakota College at Bottineau, Lake Region State College, Minot State University, and Williston State College) to extend the reach of the curriculum and support students who would like to transition to a related four-year degree program; and (5) to provide workshops, seminars, and other professional development activities to improve the cybersecurity knowledge and skills of Turtle Mountain Community College faculty.  This project will contribute to national priorities by strengthening cybersecurity education and increasing the diversity of the cybersecurity technical workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Turtle Mountain Community College (TMCC) designed the Natives in Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Program to promote improvement in information assurance/cybersecurity education and increase the number of qualified educators and technicians to meet growing workforce demands. This program was also designed to increase the participation of Native Americans, women, and veterans in 2- and 4-year cybersecurity degrees. This 5-year project began in spring 2019, and is ending this year.

These goals and objectives were crucial in setting the parameters and expectations for the NICE cybersecurity team at TMCC. Over the course of the program, there were 87 total students that participated in cybersecurity camps. These students acquired the basic skills and knowledge of cybersecurity, which in turn helped them determine their interest in future degrees. The target area has been focused on middle school and high school students, grades 5-12, to encourage enrollment in any of the certificate or degree programs offered at TMCC.

The first two camp alumni enrolled at TMCC in fall 2021, representing 17% of the cumulative total of 12 eligible to enroll as of Fall 2021. From our 2021 report: ?this exceeded rates reported in a 5-year evaluation of GenCyber camp host universities where alumnae enrollment rates ranged from 1% to 7% for schools hosting camps from 1 to 3 years.? The average annual enrollment at TMCC for students that participated in the camps was 22 while the number of certificates and AAS degrees earned totaled 21. These numbers reflect an increase in cybersecurity students, especially in a new and rising cybersecurity program at TMCC where total overall enrollment over 600 is considered a great year. Out of those students, 18 of them are retained annually. These numbers also show positive enrollment, considering the global pandemic that the world endured from 2020-2022 that all but shut any public interaction down.

The students, when polled, responded that some of the challenges they endured during this time made attending classes very difficult. TMCC responded by offering an all-virtual program to ensure students were safe while still able to pursue their educational goals. Through this experience, TMCC recognized the advantages of integrating remote learning into their program and adapted a hybrid program in 2021. TMCC continues to offer a hybrid program to provide needed flexibility for students and the opportunity for students to continue their program under changing circumstances, including moving away from the community to accommodate families and work.

Nearly all survey respondents agreed or strongly agreed that they had sufficient access to resources, internships were relevant, courses were preparing them to succeed in a cybersecurity careers, and that instructors are knowledgeable, respectful and concerned about them and that the program is preparing them to succeed in a cybersecurity career. The respondents who used student services reported these services are helping them gain skills, build motivation, and feel supported. Overall, they agreed that the student services they used had helped them to gain useful skills, build their motivation to complete their certificate or degree, feel supported academically and emotionally, and be more successful at TMCC. Over three quarters of students (77%) report their overall perception of the program as good or excellent. Students also reported that a hybrid program with a mix of online and in-person coursework and support was helpful, and that they would like more hands-on projects, labs, programs, instructors, and equipment to improve the program. When asked what helped them stay in school, respondents reported that instructors had the greatest impact, followed by academic advisors, financial stability, extracurricular activities, work study programs, new student orientation/making friends, and study groups.

This project has taught us many lessons as we move forward in our efforts to advance cybersecurity technology at TMCC. Data shows that students appreciate the quality of instruction and have positive relationships with the faculty and staff. They also appreciate the support services they have participated in and attribute those supports to supporting their success. The program has successfully recruited participation in multiple cybersecurity summer camps for middle and high school students and 9-month certificate and 2-year AAS Degree programs at TMCC, even under impacts of the pandemic. TMCC students are completing industry recognized certifications, 9-month certificates, and 2-year degrees. Surveys indicate that students are having a positive experience at camp and learning about cybersecurity careers.

I would like to express our sincere gratitude for your support of our cybersecurity programs. Your funding has been instrumental in helping us to develop a world-class program that is preparing students for the high-demand cybersecurity workforce. 

Turtle Mountain Community College's cybersecurity program is growing rapidly. To learn more visit our website at https://www.tmcc-cyber.com.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2023
Modified by: Chad J Davis
